course.subject: ELEC
course.name: Data-Driven Portfolio Optimization
course.description: Modern portfolio theory started with Harry Markowitz's 1952 seminal paper "Portfolio Selection." He put forth the idea that risk-adverse investors should optimize their portfolio based on a combination of two objectives: expected return and risk. Until today, that idea has remained central in portfolio optimization. However, the vanilla Markowitz portfolio formulation does not seem to behave as expected in practice and most practitioners tend to avoid it. During the past half century, researchers and practitioners have reconsidered the Markowitz portfolio formulation and have proposed countless of improvements and alternatives such as robust optimization methods, alternative measures of risk, regularization via sparsity, improved estimators of the covariance matrix, robust estimators for heavy tails, factor models, volatility clustering models, risk-parity formulations, index tracking, etc. This course will explore the Markowitz portfolio optimization in its many variations and extensions, with special emphasis on Python programming.
course.prerequisites: (IEDA 2510 (prior to 2018-19) OR IEDA 2520 OR IEDA 2540 OR ELEC 2600) AND (MATH 2111 OR MATH 2121 OR MATH 2131 OR MATH 2350)
